strings.text: Software engineering oriented to stability, automation, and critical systems.
Focused on stability, automation, and existing systems. From critical infrastructure to software engineering.
Two decades of evolution. From critical infrastructure to
"The peak of responsibility. Eight years at the financial core where tolerance for error was zero."
Ensured uninterrupted operation of core banking systems in a 24/7 environment. Built PowerShell automation to standardize operations across thousands of servers.
24/7 banking environment. Zero tolerance for failures.
Operational discipline: automation, observability, and change control in 24/7 environments.
I bring that operational discipline into software: predictable delivery, safe changes, and long-term reliability.
"Industrial robustness. Every stopped system had an immediate, tangible physical cost."
IT support in a demanding industrial environment where downtime had immediate physical impact. Networks, terminals, and logistics operations.
Refinery and heavy logistics environment. Physical pressure for rapid resolution under adverse conditions.
Robustness first: design for failure and recovery, not best-case paths.
That resilience mindset translates into software that degrades gracefully and stays maintainable.
"The era of scale. Where I learned that large infrastructures are built in layers of abstraction."
Supported early cloud and virtualization at scale—bridging physical infrastructure and logical layers.
Managing complexity at scale. Understanding how virtual instances interact without physical conflicts.
Systemic thinking: understand the full architecture before acting on isolated components.
I apply this systemic view to build modular, scalable software.
"The human foundation. Between the early technical work and multicultural management in Oslo, I learned the value of communication."
Started in 1999 as an IT technician. This was followed by a deliberate and enriching break in the Tourism and Customer Success sector in Oslo.
High-turnover multicultural environments. Managing expectations and rapid problem diagnosis under social pressure.
Empathy as diagnosis. Understanding the user's pain is half of the technical solution.
I translate complex business needs into code that solves real problems.
Focus on Python and the art of
For me, code is a tool for stability. Skill levels are living indicators—reviewed continuously from real practice, formal training, and active projects.
Programming I & II – University of Helsinki
Structured and demanding training. Mastery of algorithms, data structures, and OOP with Python.
I moved from technical support to programmatic computing. Where others see a script, I see a resilient automation system.
Able to work autonomously in backend and automation, with attention to robustness and maintenance.
Code quality and maintenance best practices
Formal consolidation of foundations already used in real operations. EQF level 4. Includes a 210h internship (FCT).
Reinforces architectural fundamentals and disciplined delivery for robust, scalable applications.
Fullstack contribution with focus on quality and maintainability.
Level 5 cybersecurity specialization course aligned with the official skills framework, with a strong practical component and internship (485h). The CET internship starts around April 2027 (approx.).
The CET program expands and deepens the foundation built in EFA, combining programming, networking and systems fundamentals with advanced cybersecurity practices, monitoring and incident response.
Cumulative technical profile (EFA + CET): a solid software and operations base strengthened with hands-on cybersecurity, compliance and operational defense skills.
Security Applied to Development and Data
Detection and analysis of vulnerabilities in web applications and networks
Collection, normalization and analysis of security logs and evidence
Automation of hardening and monitoring tasks with scripts
Secure configuration of operating systems, services and network infrastructure
Application of algorithms, structured programming and databases in security contexts
Implementation of security policies and access control
Configuration and hardening of client and server systems
Technical documentation and operational communication in incident contexts
Integration between security, development and operations (DevSecOps mindset)
My reasoning is deterministic. I believe in the process, the right timing for each step, and the absolute isolation of variables to solve any problem.
"My structured family life and these real hobbies shape how I work: discipline in the process, attention to detail, and consistency."
I am married and have a 13-year-old son. Adoption was a long, structured, demanding, and regulated process that requires patience, predictability, emotional stability, and consistent routines.
This path reinforced critical skills for long projects: consistency, predictability, and commitment to processes.
Making bread is a regular hobby of mine. In artisan bread, skipping steps destroys the result. Fermentation time is a dependency that can't be rushed without compromising structure.
In software, robust architectures require the right time for design and validation. Respecting dependencies and code maturation time avoids catastrophic technical debt.
Making pizza at home is a hobby of mine. A perfect pizza is the result of small adjustments each batch. Temperature, hydration, time—every detail is tuned based on the previous result.
Programming is iteration. I prefer small, frequent deliveries that allow quick course correction, ensuring the final product aligns with reality.
Gel nail maintenance is a manual hobby of mine. It taught me that preventing is cheaper than repairing. Small, frequent care avoids bigger failures and preserves integrity.
In software, prevention is constant refactoring, regular testing, and daily attention to detail. The same logic avoids silent failures and keeps systems reliable over the years.

The initial contact with digital marketing wasn't planned. It arose during gel nail training: most nail technicians work alone, so the course included marketing notions. Continued exposure to the topic led me to self-study.
For me, marketing is not a parallel career—it's product awareness. It translates into three pillars: thinking about the end user, communicating clearly, and delivering value before technology.
I follow laws and electoral systems as a personal and structural interest, not political. It’s a fascination with explicit rules, procedural precision, and system integrity.
I see this as a structured cognitive exercise, similar to a systems audit: sound data, auditable transitions, and clear rules at each step.
This shows that I value the right timing, prevention, and continuous care—and I apply that logic every day in software.
Who I am shows in how I

I've worked with technology since the late 90s, with a strong base in critical systems, automation, and 24/7 infrastructure. I re-entered software development focused on continuity, predictability, and technical quality.

I am married and have a 13-year-old son; that family stability translates into focus, predictability, and technical reliability at work. I bring to code the discipline of environments where failure wasn't an option.
Beyond the technical side, I have training in value communication, metrics, and product awareness—useful to align decisions, language, and impact with the end user.
CET Technical Specialist in Cybersecurity (Level 5, 1,510h, in progress)
24/7 banking infrastructure with zero tolerance for failures
BNP Paribas, CEPSA, Telefónica — environments where stability was absolute.
University of Helsinki (270h) + EFA IT Programmer (1,416h). C/C++, C#, Java, Python, SQL.
Absolute rigor and stability as a continuous process
The mindset built in critical environments now applies to software development.
Ability to work in international teams and communicate with global stakeholders.
Married, father of a 13-year-old — focus and predictability
That family stability translates into technical reliability and long-term commitment.
Value communication, metrics, and product awareness
Complementary training that helps think about the end user and communicate clearly.
Access my professional documents and certifications.
What I'm looking for at this
Available for a curricular internship (210h) in a real development or systems context, able to contribute effectively from day one.
The theoretical component ends in late June, and the internship can start from June 2026.
Preference for remote (nationwide) and a hybrid alternative in the Bragança area.
The internship is supervised by the training provider, with an individual plan and defined objectives.
Does not require basic training — I'm already used to real work contexts and systems with history.
Contact helps align expectations and context.
Available for projects where technical maturity and human commitment make the difference.
Tools for value communication, metrics, and positioning (19/20)
